dating.remarks: [Letter from D. Koepplin to the Dorotheum, Vienna, 14.01.2003; Koepplin Archive]

pageContext.description:
The sitter is depicted as a half-length figure in three quarter profile against a dark green curtain and looking to her right. Her elaborate dress of gold brocade with slit sleeves and a high collar bears a motto around the neckline, embroidered with pearls. She wears a bonnet with her monogram ‘M’ and a plaited bridal wreath on her head, both are decorated with pearls. Three large chains, one with a pendant shaped like a wheel, a precious stone and a pearl drop, as well as two rings on her right hand complete her rich attire. 
[cda 2020]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 48.2 x 31.8 cm
[Dorotheum online database, accessed 07.09.2020](https://www.dorotheum.com/de/l/1939702/)
pageContext.inscription:
- pearl embroidery around the sitter's neckline, in three bands:
'E.N.O.F.A.E. // N.OF.A.E. // .N.O.F.A.' 
- embroidered with pearls on her head attire:
'M'

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
Summary of examination report (see attached pdf):
Support:
- thinned and cradled

Paint Layers:
- minor losses e. g. area of the cheeks, white lining and along the bottom edge
- some small retouches in the face and lower 5/6 cm of the panel
- generally in good condition

Coatings:
- uniform layer of varnish
- small cleaning test visible on the right shoulder

[Unpublished examination report, I. Sandner, 06.11.2002; Koepplin Archive]

tests.text:
Summary of an examination report (see attached pdf):

- probably beech wood panel

- dimensions (48.2 x 31.8 cm) correspond with the standard format C used in the Cranach workshop

- an underdrawing is visible in the infrared reflectogram and is characterized by faint lines defining the main contours and describing essential details; probably executed using dark chalk

-

- the x-radiograph illustrates the characteristic rational technique employed in the Cranach workshop for rendering the flesh paint. 

- it also shows that very few alterations were made during the painting process: only the eyes appear to have been originally posiitioned somewhat lower down. 

- the infrared reflectogram on the other hand shows corrections made to the sleeve during the painting process

[Unpublished examination report, I. Sandner, 06.11.2002; Koepplin Archive]
